title: Why don't Americans usually write the year in full, like '2020' instead of just '20'? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is an eliptical expression. Typically we abbreviate it as ‘20. An elipsis is a figure of speech that omits words that are understood by the reader, who, by context, knows to supply them. That way, Bon Jovi didn’t have the awkward-sounding, “Summer of Nineteen Sixty Nine” as a song title and lyric that would not fit the rest of the song.

If you mean why do Americans say “twenty-twenty” instead of “two thousand and twenty” it’s because it’s a shorter way of saying it. If you mean why Americans call the year “‘20” instead of “2020” it’s because it’s just an abbreviation. Kind of like “summer of ‘69” or “back in ‘98”. Quicker to say.
